Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multi-Mode Electron Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor William Yu from Lousiana State University - Shreveport and colleagues Kui Che, M. Cran Lucas and Thomas Ticich will acquire a high resolution electron microscope (EM) with TEM (transmission), SEM (scanning), STEM and ED (electron difraction) functions. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) glycosaminoglycans and podocyte behavior, (b) study of anti-cancer agents based on fusarochromanone (FC101a), (c) magnetic nanocrystals for cancer detection and treatment, (d) inhibiting lymphatogenous tumor metastasis by nanoshell-mediated hyperthermia, (e) TEM analysis of carbon nanostructures synthesized in an ethanol burner, (f) porous stainless steel supported iron oxide nanoparticle membranes for arsenic removal from water, and (g) disruption of crystalline cellulose for efficient enzymatic adsorption and hydrolysis.

An electron microscope uses high energy electrons in the characterization of materials. In the transmission mode, a beam of electrons penetrates a thin layer of sample resulting in an image of the sample while in the scanning mode the electrons are used to probe the material. The electron microscope can provide higher resolution and magnification than a microscope using light to probe the material. It can provide useful details of the material down to near atomic size levels. This instrumentation will provide microscopy training and research opportunities to large numbers of students across many fields including chemistry, biology, physics, materials and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Researchers from LSUS and neighbor institutions involve in many projects studying a variety of advanced nanomaterials and cell activities including magnetic nanostructures, carbon nanotubes, arsenic removal, cell activity, bioimaging, cancer diagnosis and treatment, biofuel-related cellulose, and more. These research projects require the use of electron microscopes. This EM substantially increases our characterization capabilities and enables micro-nanoscale study on a variety of materials and structures. 9 research articles using this EM have been published, 8 related talks have been delivered on conferences, and 2 patents have been filed. 7 faculty members from the Departments of Chemistry and Biology in LSUS, Department of Pathology, LSU Health Science Center in Shreveport (LSUHSC-S) used this EM and the a few new collaborations therefore were established.

Broader Impact: LSUS is a primarily undergraduate and the only 4-year public higher education institute in the Shreveport metro area serving the Ark-La-Tex tri-state region (25% below poverty level). Louisiana is an NSF EPSCoR state receiving a low level of discretionary grant funding. Acquisition and utilization of the EM system support an improved learning environment for integrating research and education and fosters collaborations within LSUS and across the local institutions. The research training and education supported by this EM system contribute to the development of a skilled workforce to serve the local economy development. 7 faculty members and 15 graduate students have been trained to use it; two EM lab modules were added to the senior instrumental analysis and physical chemistry lab courses. Two local companies contacted us for characterizations.
